Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Acute Kidney Disease Post-Acute Kidney Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either structured follow-up care (intervention) or standard care (control).

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted in a hospital setting. Adult patients with AKI were eligible.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either structured follow-up care (intervention) or standard care (control).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the progression to CKD within 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a reduced progression to CKD (hazard ratio = 0.75, 95% CI 0.60 to 0.90; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects reported.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
